Name: BENZO(K)FLUORANTHENE
Description: Benzo[k]fluoranthene is a member of naphthalenes.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Knutzen J, Solland B; Water Res 16: 421 (1982) (2) Lodovici M et al; Sci Total Environ 153: 61-8 (1994) (3) Pathirana S et al; Ecotox Environ Safety 28: 256-69 (1994) (4) Wang Z et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 1336-41 (2009) (5) Ratola N et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 58: 631-47 (2010) (6) Wild SR, Jones KC; J Environ Qual 21: 217-25 (1992) (7) Galuszka A; Chemosphere 67: 1415-22 (2007) (8) Krommer V et al; Chemosphere 67: 1956-66 (2007)
plant_concentrations.Value: Benzo(j,k)fluoranthene was detected in algae samples of bladder wrack (Fucus vesiculasus), knotted wrack (Ascophyllum nodosum), toothed wrack (Fucus serratus), red algae (Ceramium rubrum and sea belt (Laminaria saccharina) at a trace to 66 ug/kg dry weight in samples collected April 1978 to July 1979 from fjords in Norway(1). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 0.10-0.98 and 0.1-1.21 ug/kg dry weight in leaves of bay evergreen tree (Laurus nobilis) collected in Feb 1991 from nine sites in the city of Florence and six sites in the foothills surrounding Florence, Italy, respectively(2). Casuarina littorina (needles) and leaf litter collected near a roadside in Brisbane, Australia contained 72 and 114 ng/g wet weight benzo(k)fluoranthene, respectively(3). In April 2005, pine needle samples were collected from 35 sites across Liaoning, China; benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 1-11 ng/g dry weight(4). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in pine needle samples from 27 locations scattered all over the Portuguese continental territory at 1.5-16.0 and 0.6-42.4 ng/g dry weight in 19 Pinus pinea and 12 Pinus pinaster samples, respectively; samples were collected in April 2007(5). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in peels of carrots grown in sewage sludge amended soil at 1.0-1.4 ug/kg dry weight; the concn in the peels of carrots grown in unamended soil was 0.3 ug/kg dry weight(6). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 4-38 and <3-14 ng/g dry weight in moss species H. splendens and P. schreberi, respectively; samples were collected July 2005 from 10 locations in the southern part of the Holy Cross Mountains, Poland(7). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in moss samples from seven sites at 4.7-38 ng/g dry weight with a mean of 5.3 ng/g dry weight; samples were collected Sept 2005 from Wienerwald, Austria(8).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Zhao Y et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 5853-9 (2006)
plant_concentrations.Value: In August 2003, bark from 15 species of trees of different lipid content and surface area were sampled and the pseudo bark air partition coefficient (Kba) was calculated for benzo(k)fluoranthene. The trees were located in Xiamen, China(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Pathirana S et al; Ecotox Environ Safety 28: 256-69 (1994) (2) Perugini M et al; J Agri Food Chem 57:7440-4 (2009)
animal_concentrations.Value: Slugs, beetles (Platyzosteria nitida and Laxta granicollis), millipedes and earthworms collected near a roadside in Brisbane, Australia contained 19, 4-6, 19 and 14 ng/g wet weight benzo(k)fluoranthene, respectively(1). Drone honey bees (Apis mellifera) collected May-Oct 2007 from eight sample locations in Italy contained benzo(k)fluoranthene at <0.01-0.27, <0.01-0.18 and <0.01-0.10 ng/g wet weight in unpolluted, moderately polluted and polluted sites, respectively(2).
The average concentration of benzo(k)fluoranthene in two populations of sea lions (Otaria flavescens), one from Mar del Plata and the second from Punta Bermeja, Argentina were reported as follows(1):
animal_concentrations.Table: [{'Component (units)': 'Fur (ng/g fresh weight)', 'Mar del Plata': 6.66, 'Punta bermeja': 0.81}, {'Component (units)': 'Biopsy (ng/g fresh weight)', 'Mar del Plata': 13.82, 'Punta bermeja': 1.28}, {'Component (units)': 'Blood (ng/g dry weight)', 'Mar del Plata': 3.67, 'Punta bermeja': 4.98}, {'Component (units)': 'Liver (ng/g fresh weight)', 'Mar del Plata': 7.21, 'Punta bermeja': 0.67}, {'Component (units)': 'Feces (ng/g dry weight)', 'Mar del Plata': 0.77, 'Punta bermeja': 2.08}]

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Maccubbin AE et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 34: 876-82 (1985) (2) El Deeb KZ et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 78: 373-9 (2007) (3) Malik A et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 80: 134-8 (2008)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in the stomach contents of white suckers (Catastomus commersoni) at 2.08-11.08 ng/g; fish were collected in Lake Erie(1). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 16.23, 6.33 and 272.75 ng/g wet weight in muscle of bottom feeding fish (Solea solea), bivalve (Donax trunculus) and bottom feeding fish (Diplodus vulgaris), respectively; it was not detected in shrimp (Peneaus japonicus); samples were collected Feb 2004 from Abu Qir Bay, Egypt(2). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was not detected in fish samples collected 2004 to 2005 from three sites on the Gomti River, India(3).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Mix MC, Schaffer RL; Marine Environ Res 9: 193-209 (1983) (2) Mix MC, Schaffer RL; Marine Pollut Bull 14: 94-7 (1983) (3) Howard JW, Fazio T; J Assoc Off Anal Chem 63: 1077-1104 (1980) (4) Pereira WE et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 15: 172-80 (1996) (5) Pittinger CA et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 4: 379-87 (1985) (6) Pereira WE et al; Mar Pollut Bull 24: 103-109 (1992) (7) Knutzen J, Sortland B; Water Res 16: 421-8 (1982) (8) Takatsuki K et al; J Assoc Off Anal Chem 68: 945-9 (1985) (9) Nakata H et al; Ecotoxicol Environ Saf 99: 61-8 (2014) (10) Namiesnik J et al; Chemosphere 73: 938-44 (2008) (11) Fabbri D et al; Chemosphere 64: 1083-92 (2006) (12) Kucuksezgin F et al; Chemosphere 93: 1511-8 (2013)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Mussels (Mytilus edulis) from Yaquina Bay, OR contained benzo(k)fluoranthene at <2.0-4.2 ug/kg wet weight (remote site) and 8.5-22.5 ug/kg wet weight (site proximal to industry); samples were collected 1979-1980(1). Softshell clams (Mya arenaria) collected June 1976 to August 1979 from a remote site and a site proximal to industry in Coos Bay, Oregon contained 1.1-3.4 and 8.5-10.9 ppb of benzo(k)fluoranthene, respectively(2). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in oysters taken in Texas waters: Galveston Bay 0.1 and 0.4 ppb in waters approved and closed for oyster harvesting, respectively; it was not detected in oysters from Aransas Bay(3). Clams (Corbicula fluminea) collected in 1992 from Orestimba Creek, Dry Creek, Mokelumne River and Stanislaus River contained <0.5 ng/g of benzo(k)fluoranthene(4). Benzo(b,k)fluoranthene isomers were detected at 0.005-1.0 ug/g dry weight in oysters taken from a variety of locations around the US(5). Asian clams (Potamocorbula amurensis) collected from eight sites of Suisun Bay, CA contained benzo(k)fluoranthene at 46-87 ng/g dry weight(6). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in common mussel (Mytlus edulis), periwinkle (Littorina littorea), limpet (Patella vulgata), sponge (Halichondria panicea) at 6-69, 3-20, trace-39 ug/kg dry weight, respectively, in samples collected April 1978 to July 1979 from fjords in Norway(7). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in mussels, oysters, corb-shells and shortneck clams from Miyagi Prefecture, Japan at 0.32-1.16, 1.21, 0.38 and 0.29-0.80 ppb, respectively(8). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in bivalves collected July to Oct 2008 from 18 locations in Yatsushiro Sea, Japan at 0.04-10 ng/g wet weight(9). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was not detected (detection limit 1 ug/kg dry weight) in mussels (Mytilus galloprovincialis) from polluted and non-polluted areas of Mokpo Bay, Korea, collected April 10, 2004(10). Mussels (Mytilus galloprovincialis), were translocated from 20 miles off the coast of Marina de Ravenna in the Adriatic Sea to locations in 3 coastal lagoons of Ravenna, Italy; the concentration of benzo(b,k)fluoranthene was <5 ng/g dry weight, measured before and after 30 days of relocation(11). Mussels (Mytilus sp.) from nine locations along the Aegean coast, collected in 2011 did not contained benzo(k)fluoranthene(12).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Naes K et al; Sci Total Environ 163: 93-106 (1995) (2) Cailleaud K et al; Chemosphere 70: 270-80 (2007)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Benzo(j,k)fluoranthene was detected in periwinkle (Littorina littorea) collected in 1991 from Lista, Norway in the vicinity of an aluminum smelter scrubber outfall at 385 ug/kg wet weight(1). Zooplankton (Eurytemora affinis) from the Seine Estuary (France) contained 15-559 ng/L of benzo(b,k)fluoranthene in samples collected Nov 2002 to Feb 2005(2).
Ocean organisms were collected from Central Adriatic Sea, Italy in July and December 2004. Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at the following concentrations(1):

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Uthe JF, Musial CJ; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 37: 730-8 (1986)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: The concentration of benzo(k)fluoranthene in lobster (Homarus americanus) following 3 months exposure to creosoted timbers and transfer to clean water for 13 days was 100-530 and 2-19 ng/g wet weight in the digestive gland and tail muscle, respectively. Lobsters harvested 1982 and 1984 from the south arm of Sydney Bay and from Port Morien, Nova Scotia, Canada and lobsters harvested from Sydney Harbor in 1984 then transferred to laboratory conditions for 12 months had the following benzo(k)fluoranthene concentrations(1):

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Lo M, Sandi E; Res Rev 69: 35-86 (1978) (2) Lodovici M et al; Food Addit Contam 12: 703-13 (1995) (3) Dennis MJ et al; Food Chem Toxicol 21: 569-74 (1983)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Benzo(k)fluoranthene has been detected in smoked and scorched Japanese horse mackerel (Trachurus japonicus) at 0.2 ppb and in respective Japanese fish dishes of katsuobushi, sababushi and urumebushi at 3-12, 2 and 1 ppb(1). The compound was reported at 0.012, 0.27 and 0.017 ug/kg in trout, cod and dried cod, respectively, obtained from supermarkets in a survey conducted 1985 to 1988 in Milan, Italy(2). Benzo(k)fluoranthene concentrations were measured at a range of 0.01-0.14 ppb, average 0.04 ppb in fish samples collected in the United Kingdom in 1979(3).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Lawrence JF, Das BS; Int J Environ Anal Chem 24: 113-31 (1986)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: In domestic and imported foods purchased from retail outlets and fast food chains in Toronto, Canada, benzo(k)fluoranthene was not detected (detection limit 0.002 ug/kg) in smoked herring(1). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in the following products(1):
fish_seafood_concentrations.Table: [{'Product': 'lobster paste', 'Concn (ug/kg)': '0.06-3.4'}, {'Product': 'lobster meat', 'Concn (ug/kg)': '1.2'}, {'Product': 'smoked mussels', 'Concn (ug/kg)': '0.67, 0.34'}, {'Product': 'mussels in brine', 'Concn (ug/kg)': '1.5'}, {'Product': 'smoked oysters', 'Concn (ug/kg)': '1.2-8.7'}, {'Product': 'unsmoked oysters', 'Concn (ug/kg)': '1.6'}, {'Product': 'frozen shrimp', 'Concn (ug/kg)': '<0.002-0.02'}, {'Product': 'canned shrimp', 'Concn (ug/kg)': '0.05, 1.2'}]

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Prahl FG et al; Environ Sci Technol 18: 687-93 (1984) (2) Johnson AC et al; Marine Environ Res 15: 1-16 (1985) (3) Kauss PB, Hamdy YS; Hydrobiologia 219: 37-62 (1991) (4) Murphy TP et al; Water Pollut Res J Can 26: 1-16 (1991) (5) Pereira WE et al; Mar Environ Res 41: 299-314 (1996) (6) Pereira WE et al; Mar Pollut Bull 24: 103-9 (1992) (7) Huntley SL et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 28: 93-107 (1995) (8) Echols KR et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 55: 161-72 (2008) (9) Debruyn JM et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 3467-73 (2009) (10) Hawthorne SB et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 25: 2901-2911 (2006) (11) Huang L et al; Sci Total Environ 487: 173-86 (2014) (12) Khalil MF, Ghosh U; Environ Sci Technol 40: 5681-7 (2006)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in surficial sediment samples collected Jan-Dec 1979 from coastal Washington state at 8-140 ng/g dry sediment(1) and in 49 Penobscot Bay, ME samples collected June and July1982 at 14-696 ppb dry weight(2). Benzo(b,k)fluoranthene was found in surficial sediments from the St. Mary's River, MI in 1985 at not detected to 67.0 mg/kg dry weight(3). Hamilton Harbor sediment cores collected in 1989 contained benzo(k)fluoranthene at concentrations of, 0-27.8, 0-11.4 and 0-4.6 ug/g at respective depths of 0-2, 2-4 and 10-12 cm(4). Bed sediments collected along a contamination gradient in the Lauritzen Canal, CA in 1993 contained benzo(k)fluoranthene at 59-1400 ng/g; the highest concentration occurring at the head of the canal(5). Bed and suspended sediment samples taken from Suisun Bay, CA contained benzo(k)fluoranthene at not detected to 34 and 34-37 ng/g dry weight, respectively(6). Mean benzo(k)fluoranthene concentrations in sediments from Arthur Kill, Hackensack River, Kill Van Kull, Passaic River, and Newark Bay, NJ were 1.3, 1.3, 0.92, 3.9, and 1.7 mg/kg dry weight, respectively; samples were collected Nov 1991 to March 1993(7). In 18 sediment samples collected Oct 28 to Nov 6, 2002 from 19 locations on the lower Missouri River, benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 7.0-470 ng/g dry weight(8). Seven sediment samples collected in the vicinity of a former manufactured gas plant on the Hudson River, NY contained 4.9-57.9 mg/kg of benzo(k)fluoranthene; samples were collected in 2003(9). Benzo(b,k)fluoranthene was detected in sediment samples from 114 sites from 8 historically contaminated locations in New York and North Carolina at 0.02-418 ug/g; samples were collected 2003 to 2005(10). Pore water concentrations of benzo(b,k)fluoranthene from 51 of these samples were not detected to 2.1 ng/g(10). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in sediment samples from one of seven locations on Lake Erie at 0.73 mg/kg; samples were collected in Aug 2006(11). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 10.4-44.2 ng/g dry weight in 24 samples collected Aug 16-19, 2011 from the southern part of Lake Michigan(12).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Tan YL, Heit M; Geochem Cosmochim Acta 45: 2267-79 (1981)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in sediment samples collected March 1978 from Sagamore Lake and Woods Lake, both located within the Adirondack Park, New York at the following concentrations(1):

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Martel L et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 37: 133-40 (1986) (2) Carey JH et al; Sci Tot Environ 97-98: 69-88 (1990) (3) Chapman PM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 15: 638-42 (1996) (4) Murray AP et al; Mar Pollut Bull 22: 595-603 (1991) (5) Maher WA, Aislabie J; Sci Total Environ 112: 143-64 (1992) (6) Kayal SI, Connell DW; Estuarine Coastal Shelf Sci 29: 473-87 (1989) (7) Leeming R, Maher W; Org Geochem 18: 647-55 (1992)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in surface sediment samples from the Saguenay Fjord, Quebec, Canada in Aug 1983(1). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 0.019-0.12 ug/g in eight sediments collected Aug 25-Sept 12 1985 and June 21-July 1, 1986 from the Mackenzie River, Canada(2). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was reported in sediment samples from Macaulay Point, Canada at 21-1460 ug/kg(3). Concentrations of particulate benzo(k)fluoranthene in water samples collected from various sites in Port Phillip Bay, Australia in May and August 1986 were 0.022-0.036 ng/L in water with no direct source of hydrocarbons, 0.11-0.14 ng/L in areas where the main sources of hydrocarbons is urban drainage, and 0.023-0.029 ng/L in sites close to the discharge of a major oil refinery(4). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in surface marine sediments from various locations in Australia, ug/kg dry weight: 118 in Hobsons Bay, 16-1952 (with benzo(a)fluoranthene) in George's River, 0.2 in the Clyde River, 0.1 in the Tomago River, and <0.01 in the Great Barrier Reef(5). Mean benzo(k)fluoranthene concentrations in surface sediment samples from the Brisbane River estuary, Australia were 0.08-0.35 ug/g dry weight(9). It was also detected in particulates in water from the Brisbane River estuary at a mean of 0.07-0.42 ug/g dry weight(6). It was detected in sediments from Lake Burley Griffin, Australia at 0-44 ug/kg with a mean of 12 ug/kg(7).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Sanders G et al; Chemosphere 12: 1567-82 (1993) (2) Readman JW et al; Est Coastal Shelf Sci 14: 369-89 (1982) (3) Beurskens JEM et al; Water Sci Technol 29: 77-85 (1994) (4) Domine D et al; Sci Total Environ 155: 9024 (1994) (5) Villanueva J et al; Chemosphere 22: 317-26 (1991) (6) El Deeb KZ et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 78: 373-9 (2007) (7) Fabbri D et al; Chemosphere 64: 1083-92 (2006) (8) Guo W et al; Chemosphere 68: 93-104 (2007) (9) Hiller E wt al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 83: 444-8 (2009) (10) Hori T et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 83: 455-61 (2009) (11) Li Q et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 58: 711-21 (2010) (12) Maranho LA et al; Ecotoxicology 24: 368-80 (2015)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in dated sediments from a rural English lake at concentrations ranging from not detected to 1.86 ug/g dry weight; the highest concentration was detected in sediments from 1965 to 1970, it was not detected in sediments prior to 1887(1). Tamar Estuary, England, surface sediment collected May 7, 1980 contained an avg of 336 ng/g dry weight benzo(k)fluoranthene(2). Benzo(k)fluoranthene concentrations in sediment from Lake Ketelmeer, the Netherlands, were 0.9, 1.5, and 0.5 mg/kg in 1945, 1965, and 1985, respectively(3). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in 30 sediment samples collected from 15 sampling sites of the Mediterranean Sea and the Grand Rhone river from not detected to 714.1 ng/g dry weight(4). Benzo(b,j,k)fluoranthene was detected in sediment core sections collected near an uncontrolled hazardous waste dump in North Spain at 7.2-150 ug/g(5). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in 6 of 20 sediment samples collected June 2004 form Abu Oir Bay, Egypt at 9.70-46.70 ng/g dry weight(6). Benzo(b,k)fluoranthene was detected in sediment samples from three coastal lagoons of the Adriatic Sea in Ravenna, Italy at <20-1400 ng/g dry weight(7). Sediment samples taken from the Hun, Taizi and Daliao rivers in China contained 0.62-7.61, 1.84-11.63 and 1.41-1.70 ng/g dry weight of benzo(k)fluoranthene, respectively; samples were collected Aug 2005(8). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in sediment samples collected June 2005 from the Ruzin, Velke Kozmalovce and Zemplinska Sirava reservoirs in Slovakia at 122-374, 173-382 and 2-27 ng/g dry weight(9). Benzo(b,j,k)fluoranthene was detected at 3.0-674ng/g dry weight in sediment samples collected Nov 2005 to Apr 2006 from 14 sites on the Shinano River, Japan(10). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 1.0-117.2 ng/g in sediment samples collected Sept 21, 2007 from Xiamen Bay, China(11). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at <2.00-30.94 and <2.00-44.58 ng/g in sediment samples collected in March and Sept 2011, respectively, from six sites in the Bay of Cadiz, Spain(12).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Sims RC, Overcash MR; Res Rev 88: 1-68 (1983) (2) Weissenfels WD et al; Appl Microbiol Biotechnol 36: 689-96 (1992) (3) Yu X et al; Environ Sci Technol 24: 1732-8 (1990) (4) Pathirana S et al; Ecotox Environ Safety 28: 256-69 (1994) (5) Smith DJT et al; Environ Technol 16: 45-53 (1995) (6) USEPA; Superfund Record of Decision (EPA Region 7): Doepke Disposal (Holliday), KS (First Remedial Action), September 1989, U.S. EPA (Off Emerg Rem Response, Washington, DC) USEPA/ROD/RO7-89/032; PB90-162645 (1989) (7) Jones KC et al; Environ Sci Technol 23: 95-101 (1989) (8) Leeming R; Maher W; Org Geochem 18: 647-55 (1992) (9) Berset JD, Holzer R; Int J Environ Anal Chem 59: 145-65 (1995)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in forest soil in Germany at 10 to 15 ppb(1). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in soil samples obtained from a former wood impregnation plant and a former tar-oil refinery at 41.0 and 48.5 mg/kg soil, respectively(2). Benzo(b,j,k)fluoranthenes were detected in coal tar contaminated soil from a site in Southern New Jersey at 72.4 ug/g(3). Soil and leaf litter samples collected near a roadside in Brisbane, Australia contained 78 ng/g dry weight and 114 ng/g wet weight benzo(k)fluoranthene(4). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 45.2 ug/kg in soil samples collected in Birmingham, UK and at 2.58 and 35.1 ug/kg in soil samples from Lahore, Pakistan(5). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in soil/waste samples from the Doepke-Holliday site in Johnson City, KS at 44,000 ug/kg(6). Archived soil samples from an agricultural experimental field in England had benzo(k)fluoranthene concentrations of 17, 8.4, 9, 6.2, 35, 73, 30, 250 and 58 ng/g from soil samples corresponding to respective years sampled of 1846, 1881, 1893, 1914, 1944, 1956, 1966, 1980 and 1986(7). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in soil samples from Civic and Queanbean, Australia at 41 and 25 ug/kg dry weight, respectively(8). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in 17 of 20 soil samples from the Swiss Soil Monitoring Network at a range and mean concentration of 2-38 and 9.1 ug/kg dry weight, respectively(9).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Bradley LJ et al; J soil Contam 3: 349-61 (1994) (3) Bixiong Y et al; Chemosphere 64: 525-34 (2006) (4) Cai QY et al; Chemosphere 68 159-68 (2007) (5) Essumang D et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 86: 438-43 (2011) (6) Fernando S et al; Environ Sci Technol 48: 10656-63 (2014) (7) Heywood E et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 7629-35 (2006) (8) Maliszewska-Kordybach B et al; Sci Total Environ 407: 3746-53 (2009) (9) Masih A, Taneja A; Chemosphere 65: 449-56 (2006) (10) Ortiz R et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 88: 428-32 (2012) (11) Wang Z et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 1336-41 (2009)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in soil samples collected July 21-23, 1992 from Boston and Springfield, MA, and Providence, RI at 0.043-25.00 mg/kg with an average of 1.681 mg/kg(1). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in 188 top soil samples from the Tianjin, China at an approximate geometric mean of 0.06 ug/g; areas of sampling included farmland using wastewater irrigation, common farmland, mountainous are, wild land, oil field and city greenbelt(3). Surface soils from nine representative vegetable fields located in Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Zengcheng and Huadu, China contained benzo(k)fluoranthene at not detected to 310 ug/kg; samples were collected the summer of 2002(4). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 0.08-1.0 mg/kg in soil samples collected from eight locations around the city of Esbjerg, Denmark(5). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected in soil at 2 ug/g; sample was collected from a plastics company involved in a major fire in 1997 in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada(6). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 1.07-1690 ng/g dry weight (mean and median; 54.8 and 16 ng/g dry weight) in 201 soil samples from 32 different land types collected from across Great Britain(7). In 216 soil samples collected from agricultural fields in 2005 from Poland, benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 3-422 ug/kg(8). Benzo(k)fluoranthene was not detected soil samples collected from industrial, residential or agricultural land use areas; the mean concentration for roadside use soil samples was reported as 0.39 ug/g; 319 soil samples were collected from Agra, India(9). Benzo(k)fluoranthene concentrations in dry months of 2008 were 0.52 and 0.02 ng/kg, and 0.48 and 0.86 ng/kg in wet months of 2009; samples were collected from crop lands in Mexico City, Mexico(10). In April 2005, soil samples were collected from 35 sites across Liaoning, China; benzo(k)fluoranthene was detected at 1-145 ng/g dry weight(11).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Garcia-Galcon MS et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 759-63 (2006)
